positive.review:
A clone of Honkai Impact 3 but in a good way. It captures the feel of early 3d mobile action games, something that can no longer be found in more modern games.

Runs well on a potato and doesn't take a lot of space.

**[h1]Action Taimanin: A Wild, Over-the-Top Ride Through the Shadows[/h1]**

**[b]Overall Impression[/b]**  
Man, where do I even start with *Action Taimanin*? I've sunk over 120 hours into this game at this point - mostly late nights when I just wanted to zone out and punch some demons - and I can confidently say it's one of the most aggressively fun, unapologetically weird games I've ever played. It's not perfect by any stretch, but if you're into fast-paced action, anime chaos, and a storyline that doesn't take itself too seriously (until it absolutely does), this game will grab you by the collar and drag you through hell with a grin. It's like *Devil May Cry* had a baby with a hentai visual novel, and that baby grew up to be a ninja assassin with a chainsaw katana. Yeah, it's that kind of game.

**[b]Gameplay Mechanics[/b]**  
Let's break it down. Combat is *Action Taimanin*'s bread and butter, and it's surprisingly deep for what looks like a flashy beat-'em-up. You've got a roster of Taimanin (female ninja operatives) to choose from, each with unique weapons, skills, and playstyles. I mained Asagi, because nothing says ‚Äúbadass‚Äù like dual-wielding swords and teleport slashes, but I've dabbled with Sakura, Igawa, and even the DLC characters like Murasaki. The combos are tight, the dodge mechanic (with its brief invincibility frames) feels responsive, and chaining together aerial attacks, ground slams, and ultimate moves is *chef's kiss*.

The progression system is solid - leveling up your characters, upgrading their skills, and unlocking new gear keeps things fresh. But here's the kicker: the game leans *hard* into gacha mechanics. Want that S-rank weapon or that exclusive costume with stat boosts? Better roll the in-game currency, which you earn slowly or can buy with real money. I've managed to avoid spending cash, but it's definitely there, lurking in the menus like a hungry demon. If you're not into grinding for drops, you might get frustrated, especially in the later stages when enemy HP balloons.

Exploration is pretty linear - most missions are corridor-based brawls with occasional branching paths - but there's a weird charm in how much content is crammed into each level. Hidden items, optional bosses, and side quests pop up often enough to keep you poking around. Puzzles? Not really a thing here. This is all about slicing, dicing, and dodging. But hey, sometimes you just want to cut loose, right?

One gripe: the camera can get *janky* during big fights, especially in enclosed spaces. And don't get me started on some of the later mission objectives - defend this NPC for 90 seconds while waves of enemies spawn? That's not fun; that's tedious. Still, the combat is so satisfying that I usually push through.

**[b]Graphics and Sound[/b]**  
Visually, *Action Taimanin* is a mixed bag - but mostly in a good way. The character models are gorgeous, with detailed animations and a ton of customization options. The art style nails that Japanese anime aesthetic, especially during cutscenes, which are dripping with drama and... well, fanservice. If you're into that sort of thing (and let's be real, if you're playing this game, you probably are), you'll be happy. Enemy designs range from cool to outright goofy - there's a boss that's literally a giant sentient d*ck with arms - but in a game this absurd, it kinda works.

Environments are decent but repetitive. You'll fight in demon-infested labs, neon-lit city streets, and ancient Japanese temples, but after the 10th time running through a warehouse with flickering lights, you start to wonder if the level designer took a shortcut. Still, the lighting effects and particle work during combat make up for it - seeing Asagi's sword ignite with fire magic while she's flipping through the air never gets old.

Soundtrack? Fire. The opening theme alone is worth the price of admission. The OST mixes traditional Japanese instruments with heavy synth and rock, creating this perfect blend of feudal and futuristic. Voice acting is hit or miss - some characters are voiced with serious intensity, others sound like they're reading lines in a booth after a long lunch - but it's all part of the charm. Weapon slashes, demon roars, and the satisfying *thwack* of a finishing move are all top-notch. Crank up the volume, especially with headphones.

**[b]Story and Characters[/b]**  
Okay, real talk: the story is bonkers. It starts as a straightforward ‚Äúninjas vs. demons‚Äù setup, but quickly spirals into government conspiracies, interdimensional rifts, and a villain who's basically a demonic Elon Musk with a god complex. The writing is cheesy as hell, but in a way that's endearing if you lean into it. Some characters get actual development - like Fuuma Kotaro, who starts off as a typical edgy antihero but slowly reveals layers of trauma and ambition. Others? They're there to look hot and slice things. And honestly? That's fine.

The worldbuilding is surprisingly fleshed out for a game that's mostly about combat. There's lore hidden in item descriptions, side conversations, and optional missions. If you're into the Taimanin universe (which originated from visual novels and manga), you'll appreciate the nods to the source material. If not, it's still easy enough to jump in and enjoy the ride. Just don't expect Shakespeare - this is more like a B-movie action flick with boobs and blood splatter.

**[b]Personal Experience[/b]**  
I'll never forget the first time I fought the giant spider-demon in Chapter 5. I was under-leveled, out of healing items, and the camera kept getting stuck behind walls. I died six times in a row, swearing at my monitor like it owed me money. Then, on the seventh try, I nailed a perfect parry, triggered a slow-mo kill streak, and finished her off with a super move that lit the whole screen on fire. I actually cheered out loud. My roommate thought I'd gone insane.

Another moment: playing through the ‚ÄúWhat If‚Äù scenarios after beating the main story. Seeing alternate versions of characters - like a brainwashed Sakura going full yandere - was equal parts disturbing and fascinating. It's clear the devs had fun with these side stories, and it shows.

Oh, and the fan service? It's *everywhere*. Costumes, victory poses, dialogue choices that lead to... *intimate* scenes. If you're not into that, you can skip it, but it's woven into the progression system (some stat boosts only come from ‚Äúbonding‚Äù missions). I personally just toggle on the ‚Äúskip all H-scenes‚Äù mod from the Steam Workshop and call it a day.

**[b]Recommendation[/b]**  
So, should you buy it?  
If you're a fan of character action games, anime aesthetics, and don't mind a little (or a lot) of ecchi content, *absolutely*. It's not going to win Game of the Year, but it's a blast if you're in the mood for something chaotic and stylish. The combat is tight, the customization is deep, and the sheer amount of content - main missions, side ops, challenge modes, and endless gear farming - will keep you busy for a long time.

But if you're looking for a deep narrative experience, hate grinding, or are easily offended by... *suggestive* character designs, maybe steer clear. Also, the game *does* have some rough edges - camera issues, repetitive level design, and the ever-present temptation to spend real money on gacha pulls.

That said, I've had more $20 well spent than I care to admit. *Action Taimanin* is dumb fun with heart, and sometimes, that's exactly what you need. Just go in with your eyes open - and maybe a controller in hand.

this is the diet path of exile - but it gets better, devs actually care... about all that money that can be made from nice products

i was thinking of an accessible game, meaning minimalistic graphics, and this is it, overall quite simple too (mobile version has some weird restrictions on it)

this one is less like watching kittens, more like watching lions tear [strike]minorities[/strike] demonic terrorists apart in the [strike]arena[/strike] streets of japon and such, which look amazing despite minimalism (no need to run 40km for hours before all that)

it is simultaneously relatively low and high budget game, probably making monthly what bestseller indie slop makes from popularity; there are thus wealthy whale players that fund the game massively, but playing for free looks more reasonable (you likely have to spend a fortune to get notably boosted)

progression is supposed to take a long time (and you dont get wiped and nerfed into nothingness btw) - it may seem like unlocks could take ages, but in 1 to 5 months one could unlock effectively most taimanins, or most that matter or your favorites, and in that time 3 got released for 38 total

thats like 38+ builds and styles to play, something that would instead take eternity to build in path of exile if that much variety existed at all (if only over entire history) - some styles suck however - ultimately your base could produce resources to skip grinding and playing what you don't like

the gameplay challenges can range from easy mode story to ridiculously tough battles, often these extremes, tough endgame modes are pretty much top tier resource farming, pvp arena is similar, even if you most likely will be facing endless whale players - it does not really matter, so there is no competition; instead clubs and friends give benefits from cooperation

main story with 3d built into visual novel style is pretty good, fully voiced, unlike many others i suppose, classic japanese story rollercoaster being like sadge cbt session switching into cute and funny slice of life comedy into genocide terrorism arson ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• into funny and so on (this is a timeline where nothing ever happens - kinda nice and comfy one)

there is a lot of stuff to collect and hoard i suppose, much more conveniently than in poe and for free, there is also something like 300+ days of rewards given out, which gives some major progress even if you are barely playing (tho i spent like 5$ to deal with one annoying jumpscare supporter offer - being 5 units for farming, probably first one maxed out)

it has a solid metal soundtrack and other storytelling variety, not too much variety, that part didn't see improvement over time, but there is also probably a trillion of nice voice actors too, it is sweet - overall 10/10 i like everything, could play forever and this is the good measure of a game - would you like to come back everyday? if not - then why bother with lackluster slop that must be repulsive on every level (and not appealing to anyone at all)

I've sunk over 120 hours into this game at this point - mostly late nights when I just wanted to zone out and punch some demons - and I can confidently say it's one of the most aggressively fun, unapologetically weird games I've ever played. It's like *Devil May Cry* had a baby with a hentai visual novel, and that baby grew up to be a ninja assassin with a chainsaw katana. Yeah, it's that kind of game.

One gripe: the camera can get *janky* during big fights, especially in enclosed spaces. And don't get me started on some of the later mission objectives - defend this NPC for 90 seconds while waves of enemies spawn? That's not fun; that's tedious. Still, the combat is so satisfying that I usually push through.

Visually, *Action Taimanin* is a mixed bag - but mostly in a good way. The character models are gorgeous, with detailed animations and a ton of customization options. The art style nails that Japanese anime aesthetic, especially during cutscenes, which are dripping with drama and... well, fanservice. If you're into that sort of thing (and let's be real, if you're playing this game, you probably are), you'll be happy. Enemy designs range from cool to outright goofy - there's a boss that's literally a giant sentient d*ck with arms - but in a game this absurd, it kinda works.

Environments are decent but repetitive. You'll fight in demon-infested labs, neon-lit city streets, and ancient Japanese temples, but after the 10th time running through a warehouse with flickering lights, you start to wonder if the level designer took a shortcut. Still, the lighting effects and particle work during combat make up for it - seeing Asagi's sword ignite with fire magic while she's flipping through the air never gets old.

Soundtrack? Fire. The opening theme alone is worth the price of admission. The OST mixes traditional Japanese instruments with heavy synth and rock, creating this perfect blend of feudal and futuristic. Voice acting is hit or miss - some characters are voiced with serious intensity, others sound like they're reading lines in a booth after a long lunch - but it's all part of the charm. Weapon slashes, demon roars, and the satisfying *thwack* of a finishing move are all top-notch. Crank up the volume, especially with headphones.

**[b]Story and Characters[/b]**  
Okay, real talk: the story is bonkers. It starts as a straightforward ‚Äúninjas vs. demons‚Äù setup, but quickly spirals into government conspiracies, interdimensional rifts, and a villain who's basically a demonic Elon Musk with a god complex. The writing is cheesy as hell, but in a way that's endearing if you lean into it. Some characters get actual development - like Fuuma Kotaro, who starts off as a typical edgy antihero but slowly reveals layers of trauma and ambition. Others? They're there to look hot and slice things. And honestly? That's fine.

The worldbuilding is surprisingly fleshed out for a game that's mostly about combat. There's lore hidden in item descriptions, side conversations, and optional missions. If you're into the Taimanin universe (which originated from visual novels and manga), you'll appreciate the nods to the source material. If not, it's still easy enough to jump in and enjoy the ride. Just don't expect Shakespeare - this is more like a B-movie action flick with boobs and blood splatter.

I'll never forget the first time I fought the giant spider-demon in Chapter 5. I was under-leveled, out of healing items, and the camera kept getting stuck behind walls. I died six times in a row, swearing at my monitor like it owed me money. Then, on the seventh try, I nailed a perfect parry, triggered a slow-mo kill streak, and finished her off with a super move that lit the whole screen on fire. I actually cheered out loud. My roommate thought I'd gone insane.

Another moment: playing through the ‚ÄúWhat If‚Äù scenarios after beating the main story. Seeing alternate versions of characters - like a brainwashed Sakura going full yandere - was equal parts disturbing and fascinating. It's clear the devs had fun with these side stories, and it shows.

Oh, and the fan service? It's *everywhere*. Costumes, victory poses, dialogue choices that lead to... *intimate* scenes. If you're not into that, you can skip it, but it's woven into the progression system (some stat boosts only come from ‚Äúbonding‚Äù missions). I personally just toggle on the ‚Äúskip all H-scenes‚Äù mod from the Steam Workshop and call it a day.

So, should you buy it?  
If you're a fan of character action games, anime aesthetics, and don't mind a little (or a lot) of ecchi content, *absolutely*. It's not going to win Game of the Year, but it's a blast if you're in the mood for something chaotic and stylish. The combat is tight, the customization is deep, and the sheer amount of content - main missions, side ops, challenge modes, and endless gear farming - will keep you busy for a long time.

But if you're looking for a deep narrative experience, hate grinding, or are easily offended by... *suggestive* character designs, maybe steer clear. Also, the game *does* have some rough edges - camera issues, repetitive level design, and the ever-present temptation to spend real money on gacha pulls.

That said, I've had more $20 well spent than I care to admit. *Action Taimanin* is dumb fun with heart, and sometimes, that's exactly what you need. Just go in with your eyes open - and maybe a controller in hand.

Guys please include walking animations too so that I can goon properly. The game is so good it has so many waifus that it won my heart. You guys are cool.

This is a good Taimanin waifu collector and is pretty F2P friendly. Characters aren't even in the gacha, just the supporters and weapons to improve them. You can simply acquire the characters (except Annerose) when you have enough gems which you can generate pretty quickly if you're patient.

The only thing that requires real money are the limited skins for characters in packages or battle passes. But other than that, you can get everything else for free when you play enough daily.

As an action game though? It's bad. The controls are abyssmal. There is likely no I-frames for dodges and it has cooldown. Attack cancel is clanky. And the targeting is way too strong. Enemies also attack in swarm giving you no time to breathe while evading their attacks.
In addition with those bad controls, missions have conditions to get stars. And in the hard difficulty, one of those conditions is "Get hit less than 30 times" which is doable but frustrating to clear. The best solution is to basically defeat the enemies before they can jump you.

TLDR: This game is a good waifu collector for the gooners and Taimanin fans, but has terrible gameplay for combat. Skill issue? Maybe. Or maybe not. You decide.

Honestly it gave me some stimulation during an important phone call that I already can‚Äôt recall. Would not pay money for this game but it‚Äôs good being free at the time of writing this.

Action Taimanin is an exhilarating action game that draws from the popular Taimanin series, blending elements of action and role-playing adventure seamlessly. Players step into the shoes of the Taimanin, skilled warriors battling against demonic forces, and the experience is nothing short of thrilling.

The dynamic gameplay keeps you engaged as you navigate through various missions and intense battles. One of the standout features is the diverse roster of characters, each equipped with unique abilities and fighting styles. This variety allows players to experiment and find the character that best suits their playstyle, adding depth to the gameplay.
Buen juego para pasar el rato. No pidas mucho, porque te va a aburrir. Pero, si eres un friki empedernido y te gustan los pixeles voluminosos, te va a gustar.
come for the boobies, stay because it's a fun game for me

would recommend if you like gatchas and wifus. lets be honest, we're all here for the wifus.

negative.review: I lost all the data I had poured into this game and there seems to be no way to recover any of it.

Quarter grinder gatcha game that wastes your time. Pretty, can run on a low end comp, but not worth the time. Cheap difficulty and a lot of redundancy. The combat system isn't horrible, but the combat experience is very P2W with obvious AI snags that will force annoying repeats.
While i love the art style and the character design, the moment to moment gameplay and story are just to mid for me to advise playing

Here‚Äôs the deal: you spend time battling demons and ninjas with flashy graphics and slick character models‚Äîno doubt it's visually striking. But underneath the pretty facade you‚Äôre stuck doing the same hack-and-slash loops, invisible walls trap you, end-game gives you little to work toward, and the monetization gets pretty hungry. 

It‚Äôs like being a bear with a shiny new fishing rod, but only catching the same tiny fish over and over. Unless you‚Äôre deeply into the aesthetic or the IP, you‚Äôll probably want something more robust.

Hack and slash without much actual hacking and slashing. Short playable boards with the common feature of opening chest for upgrades that require huge amounts of time that would be better spent on actually playing the game. The combat system is ok-ish but the enemies become almost unbeatable fairly quickly.

I had to do a fresh install of windows. Reinstalled steam started this game and my account is gone it started for where you pick your starting character. I had every character in the game except one. Both UR weapons for all of them except one. I figured it's linked to steam they even say it themselves that it auto links to steam but apparently not for me. So uninstall and removed from account since they have such a garbage account linking system.
I lost all the data I had poured into this game and there seems to be no way to recover any of it.
While i love the art style and the character design, the moment to moment gameplay and story are just to mid for me to advise playing

game's not bad but the gacha element in it is very predatory.. is the studio chinese or japanese because honestly for governments forcing their devs to steal money from everyone this cheap like this really won't get you anywhere in long term, unless the game is highly detailed i could excuse that part of efforts of skins.. mobile port too..

this game deletes all my data every time i have to re install it   any one know how to get it back? either way its not as spicy as the source material you can spend your time and on something better good characters tho

Too much unpolished, unfinished looking assets other than the characters.
You just have a little fight, with super basic control, win, level up, repeat.
There's no challenge and it's just a bit too indie.

Quarter grinder gatcha game that wastes your time. Pretty, can run on a low end comp, but not worth the time. Cheap difficulty and a lot of redundancy. The combat system isn't horrible, but the combat experience is very P2W with obvious AI snags that will force annoying repeats.
It's a waste of time for this low-quality animation, this creature is the most common clicker, which in my opinion completely disqualifies it. I don't recommend it.

I got to play this game for a total of 7 minutes. And I use the word "play" VERY loosely. There actually wasn't ANY game play in that 7 minutes. It was two minutes of loading the game, downloading an update, and skipping the intro video. Then it was 5 minutes of watching "connecting...." animate on the screen while nothing happened. Who the hell programmed this garbage, and why hasn't the obvious resume liar been canned and replaced with someone who knows how to do network programming? This is ridiculous. I'm deleting this trash and never looking back.

Hack and slash without much actual hacking and slashing. Short playable boards with the common feature of opening chest for upgrades that require huge amounts of time that would be better spent on actually playing the game. The combat system is ok-ish but the enemies become almost unbeatable fairly quickly.
Whoever gave this game a positive review needs to take a good look at themselves if they think a trash game like this is good.
